verses.text: He said to me, “Son of man, stand on your feet, and I will speak to you.”
verses.comment: God addresses Ezekiel as 'son of man,' a humble title emphasizing humanity before divine authority. This phrase is frequent in Ezekiel and points forward to Christ’s favorite self-designation (see Matt. 8:20). Standing respectfully before God also foreshadows the reverence shown in true liturgical worship.

verses.text: As He spoke to me, the Spirit entered into me and made me stand on my feet, and I heard Him speaking to me.
verses.comment: It is God's Spirit that empowers and makes one capable of hearing His voice, hinting at the necessity of grace for understanding and responding to divine revelation. The Spirit acting before the prophet's own effort parallels how the Spirit enables believers both in the Old and New Covenants.

verses.text: He said to me, 'Son of man, I am sending you to the people of Israel, to a rebellious nation that has rebelled against Me. They and their fathers have sinned against Me to this very day.'
verses.comment: Israel's rebellion is persistent, signifying humanity's continual need for conversion and repentance. The sending of a prophet, despite rebellion, reflects God's steadfast mercy and desire for restoration, calling to mind the mission Christ gives to His Apostles: to minister even to the hard-hearted (Luke 10:16).

verses.text: The descendants are impudent and stubborn. I am sending you to them, and you shall say to them, 'This is what the Lord GOD says.'
verses.comment: The prophet speaks on God’s behalf, using a formal proclamation formula, underlining the prophetic office's divine foundation. This prefigures the necessity of an authorized messenger or teaching office—ensuring God's message remains uncorrupted.

verses.text: Whether they listen or refuse to listen—for they are a rebellious house—they will know that a prophet has been among them.
verses.comment: The authenticity of the prophet's mission does not depend on the people’s response but on God’s commission. A visible sign that God speaks through His chosen messengers even in the face of rejection, reflecting how Christ and His Apostles’ authority was confirmed regardless of popular acceptance.

verses.text: And you, son of man, do not be afraid of them or of their words, though briers and thorns are with you and you live among scorpions. Do not be afraid of their words or be dismayed by their looks, for they are a rebellious house.
verses.comment: The prophet is empowered to resist opposition, even when it is painful or threatening. This parallels the call to courage in all true ministry, echoing the perseverance and boldness exemplified in early Christianity despite intense persecution (see Acts 4:29).

verses.text: You shall speak My words to them, whether they listen or refuse to listen, for they are rebellious.
verses.comment: The prophet delivers God’s Word irrespective of the hearers’ response, reinforcing the importance of faithfulness to divine command over seeking human approval. The role of the teacher is to transmit faithfully, a foreshadowing of the orderly passing down of the Apostolic teaching.

verses.text: But you, son of man, listen to what I say to you. Do not be rebellious like that rebellious house; open your mouth and eat what I give you.”
verses.comment: Ezekiel is called to internalize God's word, prefiguring the concept of receiving, meditating on, and spiritually consuming divine revelation. This points toward the necessity of truly receiving God's revelation, not merely hearing it.

verses.text: Then I looked, and I saw a hand stretched out toward me, and in it was a scroll.
verses.comment: The hand from heaven invokes earlier imagery of God’s intervention and conveys the scroll as divinely authored. Scrolls often symbolize God's revealed will—here, the prophet is directly entrusted with delivering divine revelation to the people.

verses.text: He unrolled it in front of me. On both sides of it were written words of lamentation, mourning, and woe.
verses.comment: The scroll written on both sides signifies a full and complete message—one of warning and sorrow, indicating God's justice. This underscores that divine revelation addresses not only encouragement but honest confrontation with sin. Spiritual interpretation sees this as the dual aspect of God's Word: mercy and judgment, always together in His revelation.
